newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee futures creep up, holidays slow trade.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee futures creep up, holidays slow trade.

text.p: LIFFE robusta coffee futures crept higher in quiet Thursday morning business with activity being curbed by Ascension Day holidays across Europe and in Ivory Coast.
Some Moslem countries including Indonesia, a major robusta producer, are also on holiday to mark Islamic New Year.
Volume reached just 2,636 lots by midsession.
Traders said the advance, extending Wednesday's steep gains, came on the back of arbitrage buying and continued fund stop-loss buying despite scale-up trade selling at the highs.
Benchmark July hit a session peak of $1,780 a tonne, the highest since March 11, but ended the morning trade at $1,778, still a hefty $25 up.

Technically, the contract could continue to edge towards its life high of $1,820 after filling its previous chart gap at $1,705-$1,730 in a fund-led rally on Wednesday. Support is seen intact at $1,590.
"The firm close has left it a touch overbought but the momentum is good," said Elli Gifford, an independent technical analyst. "I can't see any reason why it shouldn't go higher."
But analysts said it was doubtful if the market is gaining enough momentum to conquer a double top at $1,815 and $1,820, the recent highs.
Fundamentally, well-supplied robustas have little room on the upside with producers led by Indonesia eager to step up sales into any advance.

But roaster support on the lows could help cushion any sharp falls. The soaring arabica prices on supply tightness might encourage roasters to enhance robusta use in their blends. -- Jalil Hamid, London newsroom +44 171 542 4985
